Fields.DialogueText: Sigh. I really ought to make a list.
A list of what?
Everyone who deserves a tongue-lashing for this. It isn't right to keep a lady waiting for combat, and yet here I am - all dressed up with no one to sink.

Fields.MenuText: Only for combat, Kongou? I thought it wasn't right to keep a lady waiting, period.
Patience, Kongou. Patience.
I'd rather the party's hostess arrive before the guests of honor, rather than the other way around. Blame the Morganas for being unfashionably late, Kongou, not the messengers.

Fields.DialogueText: That's correct, Kanchou, and the longer I sit here the greater the risk I'll end up keeping someone else waiting. I have places to be, you know.
You also forgot patience, Kanchou. I'm well aware that of the top five things I need most to improve, my patience is three of them.
Be that as it may, Kanchou, the "messengers" are not off the hook. After all, I'm more than willing to bring this combat to our "guests of honor" ... if I only knew where they were!
Ha! At last! Aerial spotters have them. Either more have joined since this mob was last detected, or someone doesn't know how to count.
You don't sound worried.
Not in the least, Kanchou. I have more than enough firepower for this lot.
@BATTLE
Hmmm. The white curly wool coat has merit... That electric hat will never do. Being visible is one thing, but there are lighthouses more tasteful than that...
Drapers Record... and tearing into the latest Vogue, I see.
Kanchou! Come sit and join me, if you have time. As for the critique, someone must.
I recognize the war has London - and its vehicles - unlit at night. All the fashion houses there are touting white as a lifesaver, and coming up with ways to properly wear it at night.
New York however, only goes to blackout when there's a Morgana threat, so there's no excuse for this electric hat.
Doesn't fashion lose something if it isn't seen, though?
Between being seen with that on and being hit by a lorry without it, I'd take my chances with the lorry.
I suspect you could take your "chances" with a train at top speed.
That's kind of you to say so, Kanchou, but even I'm not indestructible.

Fields.MenuText: All you have to be is fast enough to get off the tracks, and I know you're capable of that.
You are, however, armed to the teeth.
Nice to see I don't have to remind you of that.

Fields.DialogueText: Indeed I am.
True, but against an unarmed train on its rails? Morganas offer a more challenging, worthwhile target for my munitions.
In my own element, however...
If they're so awful, it's too bad you can't convince Morganas to wear them.
To bell the cat? I doubt even one of those broken-down hooligans could be convinced. Speaking of the devils...
@BATTLE
I should have seen that coming.
Hmmm... Corsets? Bustles? Well, there's the silver lining to the war in Europe...
I'm afraid to ask.
Kanchou, an astute observer once wrote: "The clothing of a woman is a pleasure for the eye that cannot be judged inferior to the other arts." I couldn't agree more.
But the clothing of a woman isn't a static art, it's a performance. Any doll can be dressed and propped up. How she moves in - and with - a garment and accoutrements is the art.
So you're not impressed by corsets and bustles. That doesn't explain the bright side to this war, Kongou.
That was to be all the rage for the winter, if the Paris pliers of haute couture hadn't been so rudely interrupted. "Born in peacetime, created for carefree days."
More like turning back the clock and attempting to convince themselves the only good fashion existed before the Great War.

Fields.MenuText: You say all that, yet aren't you the one with the giant cumberbund?
I'm surprised, Kongou. I figured you'd be a champion of more traditional styles.
I think I'd take bad fashion over a good war.

Fields.DialogueText: My obi? A much more forgiving arrangement than a corset, Kanchou. I'll take a giant cummerbund over a gut tourniquet.
Oh, trust me... I've seen plenty of fashion failures to go with the successes these last two decades. But I've been around long enough to remember the "good old days," Kanchou. Often overrated.
Bad fashion has started wars, Kanchou.
Still, the Nazis purged the elegance out of German fashion long before the garment rationing, so they hardly have the high ground on taste either.
And the Morganas? The situation at sea probably doesn't do Paris fashion any favors...
As far as I'm concerned, Kanchou, before one can discuss whether Morganas have good or bad taste in fashion, they have to acquire taste in the first place.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, I've just taken a look at the list of crew that will join us at port...
... And someone has a bad reputation? Already?
Not exactly. It's this new radio operator on the roster.
No matter how good she is, no matter how proper her character, I must insist she be immediately reassigned.
Sight unseen? What's your issue with her? I find it hard to believe it's because she's a woman.
Of course not, Kanchou. It's because she's a Vandroogenbroeck.
And that's bad because?
She's Flemish.

Fields.MenuText: Kongou, of all the Belles out there... you have a problem with where someone comes from?
Then just send her down to the infirmary, Kongou. The Fleet wouldn't send anyone contagious, and I'm sure the medical staff can set her up with something for her throat.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I can't very well ask her to revoke her citizenship.
Thank you for making my point with that Flemish/phlegm-ish pun. That's just the kind of response I'm trying to avoid, Kanchou!
I want you to know, I have nothing against her or her ancestors.
I need a better explanation than that.
*ALARM*
You will have it, Kanchou. But first...
@BATTLE
I think I'll take that explanation of yours now, Kongou.
Absolutely, Kanchou. Simply put, I'm rather tired of the humor a certain Royal Navy aerocraft carrier has at my expense.
Royal Navy... You wouldn't be talking about Ark Royal, would you?
Kanchou, Ark Royal-san is the first Belle of the Royal Navy - and the first aerocraft carrier of said navy - that one would accuse of having a droll sense of humour.
However, she is by no means the only aerocraft carrier of that distinguished body of vessels, and to blame her for every cheap shot at my expense would be doing her a disservice.
You're right, that is an easy trap to fall into...
Hmph... That's IF her humor ever rose above being silly, at any rate... hmhmmmrpmm...
So, how is this certain royal warship rubbing you the wrong way? And how does Radioman Vandroogenbroeck fit into it?
She keeps inquiring how many Belgian nationals there are among my crew.
Let me guess... how many Belgians does it take before you're the Belgian Congo?
That's the intent, yes.

Fields.MenuText: You do realize there's a war going on, right?
And because of origin, you're willing to overlook potentially top-notch crew. That's cutting your own nose off, you know.
Please tell me this is recent, and you haven't been scrutinizing the backgrounds of every member of the crew with a French, Dutch or German name.

Fields.DialogueText: In more ways than I might care to acknowledge, Kanchou, but yes.
Somehow, I doubt that, Kanchou. Any nation that goes over a decade without a navy certainly isn't going to produce "top-notch" sailors in only a handful of months.
Only recently. But I don't have many of those, so it wasn't hard to go back and check for them, too.
Leave the crew to me, Kongou, new transfers included. As for the teasing, I'm sure she'll get tired of it.
Or sink first.
No helping her with that one.
Of course not, Kanchou.
Good to hear.
On the other hand, she has reminded me of something...
@BATTLE
But I suppose you have a point. No telling from a name how many are Yankees.
Sigh... Honestly... It is possible to go overboard on the brown leather?
Yes, at the very least a little colour is in order.
Maybe some dyed suede or chamois? Mrs. Voris might have something...

Fields.MenuText: Not a bad idea Kongou. A new ensemble for yourself should be just the thing to lift your spirits.
Voris? As in Suedes by Voris? Kongou, her workshop is on Sunset Boulevard. Somehow, I don't think you're going to be able to just order "something" from a catalogue.
Is this really necessary, Kongou? Or even affordable, for that matter?

Fields.DialogueText: I couldn't agree more. But this isn't for me.
I know that, Kanchou. We're both very busy ladies. I'll need to see when she's available, then arrange to be off the coast.
It would be less affordable to order and purchase a closet full of garments that won't get used.
This is for Kaga-san.
Kaga? You've never mentioned her being particularly unfashionable before.
She tends to focus on utility and unity with her air crews, but utility is no reason to only have one look in one's closet.
That, and it wouldn't kill her to tie her accessories together with colour.
Then, this is about...
Making sure she has at least one set of properly formal attire. She will not bow before His Imperial Majesty looking like she just came off a flight deck!
Not if I have anything to say about it.
Even if she has?
Even then. Now, if you'll excuse me, Kanchou, I have work to do.
@BATTLE
One of my planes would be a way to save time bringing her from the beach. ... You don't suppose she would have issues with water travel?
Besides, this is just for a consultation. Once I have our subject choices and measurements, then we can talk about what to order.
Your "subject"? You mean, this isn't for you?
Although, now that I think about it, having gifts to bestow on some of the Belles I know might be a subtle way to give them the hint...
Won't get used? Gifts? I thought this fashion trip was for your own wardrobe...
Let us meet in battle, and come out victorious.
@BATTLE
You're serious about this.
With all the attack missions I've volunteered for along the way, it's an all-business trip.
You were worried that the trip to see Voris Marker - a Hollywood fashion designer - would be seen as "sightseeing," while the meeting itself is "business"?

Fields.MenuText: What happens when the Morganas figure out where we're going next and beat us to the clasp?
This itinerary should more than excuse the visit at the end, Kongou. What do you have planned for an encore, a Maelstrom raid?
If we don't get there in one piece, you're going to be accused of putting us in the nearest repair dock to Los Angeles intentionally, you know.

Fields.DialogueText: What happens, Kanchou, is the slow-and-steady Belles also know where to meet us and don't dawdle. Instead of an ambush, it's more a chance for a proper, decisive cleansing of the Pacific.
Don't be silly, Kanchou. The encore comes when I send the last of the irate Morganas howling for a rematch to the bottom.
You have the most wicked sense of humor, Kanchou. Look anything less than my best for a meeting I've arranged? And for an esteemed guest? That's most amusing.
You know, Kongou, you've seemed fine with Kaga's choices up to now. What's caused you to change your mind?
Kaga-san may not be as old as I and my sisters, but she has been a part of the Imperial Japanese Navy for quite some time.
There are standards, Kanchou. When she is called to a formal setting, her attire WILL NOT disgrace that name of hers. Not on my watch.
After that, convincing her to upgrade her wardrobe should be easy.
Let us meet in battle, and come out victorious.
@BATTLE
Kongou, I know you're disappointed, but-
Say no more, Kanchou. Someone is interfering with me.
Interfering? That's a strong word...
Half the missions canceled? Lady Kaga is slow on answering my hails, as well. Clearly someone is trying to impede my progress.

Fields.MenuText: I doubt that, Kongou. I'm your captain, and I still don't get what you're trying to do...
It sounds like you're implying we have a spy on board.
I think those missions were cancelled because you bit off more than you can chew. Since she's still answering, Kaga probably has good reasons for the delay.

Fields.DialogueText: Making sure Lady Kaga has at least one set of "nice" clothes should be reason enough, I should think.
Not necessarily. I can think of Kami of the Fleet who would interfere with any prerogative of mine just to say she could...
Nonsense, Kanchou. I was actually conservative on the number of missions I volunteered for, to give the crew time to bring me to ship-shape before the meeting.
Well, no matter. There is more than one way to skin a cat.
I'm sure the cat won't be thrilled about any of them. Isn't it kind of unfair to come down so hard on just Kaga, too?
Not at all, Kanchou, since Lady Kaga is only the first on my list.
As for Lady Kaga, if she can keep track of over seventy separate aeroplanes and her own ship at the same time, she has no excuses for tardy replies.
Huh.
I thought your idea of ship-shape for a guest on the level of a fashion designer would somehow be stricter than this.
That's because I'm not meeting Mrs. Marker... Kaga-san is.

Fields.MenuText: That sounds like a fair compromise.
And you're okay with that? I'm sure talking fashion face-to-face with Voris Marker would've been a treat for you.
...And I suppose you've already got something lined up in its place. I'd prefer to be the second one to know about these things, Kongou... not the last one.

Fields.DialogueText: Call it one the sacrifices I'm willing to make to see things through, Kanchou.
There will be other opportunities, Kanchou. I consider getting Kaga-san in the hands of a professional the higher priority, so my work here is done, at least.
Our mission hasn't changed. Trust me, this is a situation I hadn't anticipated.
So what happened?
The Morganas happened. I was arranging to meet Lady Kaga after my meeting with Mrs. Marker... so she could choose from the ensembles I picked for her.
That sounds rather presumptuous, if you ask me...
Kanchou, if she already knew what she was doing, I wouldn't have to arrange all this. As a matter of fact, she agreed with me and thanked me for my efforts.
She did?
She did. Her only request was that she also meet with Mrs. Marker, to get her measurements taken.
I can see the logic in that.
Absolutely. It will make future decisions that much easier.
Unfortunately, something seems to have flushed the Morganas on our next strike, so it's going to take tracking and sinking them one or two at a time, instead of all at once.
Ah. Then the show will still go on, even if you can't be there.
That's not the way I would put it... but, yes. I put Mrs. Marker in touch with Kaga-san. In the meantime, we have work near at hand.
@BATTLE
Let us meet in battle, and come out victorious.
@BATTLE
What do you think, Kanchou? Is this flagon the lighter of the two?

Fields.MenuText: Why... so you can figure out which to refill first? Knowing your tolerance, it would seem simpler to just polish them both off.
I'm afraid to ask...
Tolerance or not, Kongou, drinking on duty is a bad example for your crew.

Fields.DialogueText: I will when I'm done. In the meantime, a rough estimate is all I need.
It's quite a simple matter, really.
I believe I'm allowed some leeway to that rule, given that so long as I have a commission, I'm on duty. My crew takes shifts to maintain that, but they do have down time.
So what's this about, then?
It's about trying to determine who to see next: Lady Aoba or Lady Nenohi.
I thought you approved of pushing the boundaries of fashion and the blending of East and West. Neither seem that radical to me.
I approve of individual taste, so long as it's in good taste. In Lady Aoba's case, there's a difference between "the West" and the WILD West. Floral cowboy boots? *Glug*
Did you just-
... Meanwhile, there's Lady Nenohi. Cheeky little faces on her boots? ... And a blade is not a dango skewer... *Glug* *Glug* *swish*
So! Lady Nenohi it is, then. Thank you, Kanchou.
But I understand your concerns. If we were at a higher state of alertness - and especially if I were imbibing something stiffer - I would wholeheartedly agree.
But this is just plonk, Kanchou. I might as well be drinking mineral water.
Let us meet in battle, and come out victorious.
@BATTLE
Now I know for sure someone is interfering with my work... "Indisposed"?!
Come on, Kongou. You aren't the only ship out here, you know. She's likely on a mission.
One practically on the other side of the globe from me? And not just Lady Nenohi, Kanchou. Lady Aoba is "unavailable" as well.

Fields.MenuText: I guess your critique will have to wait until later then.
That does sound odd. I didn't think you had an actual list, but if you do...
You're implying that there's a Morgana out there trying to conquer the oceans of the world by infecting Belles with lousy fashion, Kongou.

Fields.DialogueText: And throw me off my cause? They aren't getting off the hook that easily. Neither is the Belle aiding and abetting them.
It's all here in my head, Kanchou. However, I've not been one to hide my displeasure, so someone might have it in her head that she knows what I'll do next.
Morgana fashion sense being contagious... Now that is a truly horrific thought, Kanchou. But no, I don't believe this is the work of a Morgana.
If she thinks this is some sort of game-
I hope that's all you're implying. The Fleet has enough trouble sailing in the same direction as it is.
Insinuating that there's a Belle who would actively try to sabotage another is a serious charge, Kongou.
At the risk of stooping to Ark Royal-san's level, Kanchou, "If the shoe fits..."
Say you're right and someone is behind the scenes. It sounds like she "wins" this little contest of wills if she can keep you from your goal, and you win if you achieve it.
So what are you trying to do? Some sort of minimum fashion standard?
Make preparations for a renaming ceremony.
The doctor confirmed that my hearing is fine. Can you repeat what you said again?
Be serious, Kanchou.
I could say the same to you, Kongou. How did you get from "floral cowboy boots are no good" to new names? If you thought keeping track of rank within the Protection Fleet is tough...
That's just it, Kanchou. If I were to rattle off a list of states from the United States of America, you'd know we were about to rub elbows with battleships from the United States Navy.
Kearsarge isn't a state.
The exception that proves the rule - when she was a battleship. And now? Given what she does, hearing her name is never a good sign. My point still stands.
The Imperial Navy has an eloquent nomenclature, and while I may have been launched as a battlecruiser, I am now a battleship. I simply wish to be recognized as one in name as well as fact.

Fields.MenuText: You realize you're not the only ship with a name that doesn't fit convention, right?
It sounds like you may be questioning the judgement of your Commander in Chief with this one.
I think I need a drink...

Fields.DialogueText: I do. It's why I want to make sure all Belles from the Empire of Japan have at least one set of clothes appropriate for visiting the Emperor. That's something they'll thank me for, later.
Emperor Meiji himself gave me my name, Kanchou. But that was a long time ago and a great deal has changed between then and now.
Isn't having step one be a dress check kind of putting the cart before the horse? It sounds like you haven't even submitted the request yet.
I haven't. Usually that would be true, but making sure everyone is prepared to receive a summons is the harder task, so I've chosen to tackle it first.
Both will wait, however. My spotter plane has sighted a modest Morgana armada... and they're radioing the discovery back to us now. This should be amusing.
@BATTLE
And if the example encourages other members of the Protection Fleet to petition their leaders? It won't be the first time I have set the standard before.
I will abide by the decision of His Imperial Majesty, of course, but since I have the ability to suggest it, I see no harm in making the request.
Let us meet in battle, and come out victorious.
@BATTLE
So she's the one. I should have guessed...
She?
Lady Kumano. I spoke to Kaga-san to follow up on her meeting with Voris Marker.
So, did you succeed in putting an aircraft carrier in Suedes by Voris?
Not yet. I seems Mrs. Marker herself was dissatisfied with her offerings once they met. In order to "do right" by Kaga-san, she has ordered special materials.
So things are on hold... but it does sound promising.
I agree. ... It seems she went to Lady Kumano for advice, however.
I don't see how that makes Kumano "the one," Kongou.
Oh, she's the one all right. What if a bird doesn't want to sing? What is your answer, Kanchou?
I know there are three answers to that one, Kongou. For me...

Fields.MenuText: "Kill, it!" said Nobunaga. And replace it with one that does. It's that simple.
"Make it want to sing," said Hideyoshi. You said it yourself, Kongou.
"Wait," said Ieyasu. ... After confirming it's a songbird in the first place, of course....

Fields.DialogueText: An oversimplification perhaps, but I won't disagree. It's certainly the most efficient way, at times.
I did say that. I'd also say that the Toyotomi method can be further broken down into making it sing with either a hungry cat or with a handful of birdseed.
Of course. And that is why I am your ship.
I asked Lady Kumano that once.
And?
She said it depends on the songbird.
I happen to be perfectly willing to use the stick before I try the carrot.
Kanchou, we were offered a mission... but why did you reject it?
I thought you wanted time to meet with Kumano.
Ah, that. I appreciate the thoughtful gesture, Kanchou, but I've already been in contact with her.

Fields.MenuText: Then it sounds like we can accept it after all.
It appears you worked things out.
So, are you keen to take your frustrations out on some poor, hapless Morgana, or are you trying to stay one step ahead of her response?

Fields.DialogueText: Hai, if it's not too late...
Why wouldn't we? We're both calm, rational Kami.
Neither, Kanchou.
So, I'm assuming she wasn't able to talk you out of all this.
She made no attempt to. She merely asked if I had considered the new names for everyone who would require them. Since I had, she inquired as to what I would propose for her.
Light cruisers are named for rivers, while heavy cruisers and battlecruisers get mountains. Well?
The source of the Kumano River.
Oh oh.
It's nothing serious, Kanchou, but if it takes great effort to make sure all Kami are presentable enough for a formal ceremony...
... Then I might want to concentrate on the ones who require the most work.
Take on your toughest cases first, then the rest will fall into place. Who knows? The Belles least likely to give you trouble might get proactive.
You know - sprucing up before you even have to say anything?
Hai! You're right! It would be the best use of my time and talents. Meanwhile, Kumano-san can focus on Lady Nenohi and Lady Aoba for me.
You trust her with that?
Absolutely, Kanchou. As vexing as she can be at times, I can rely on Kumano-san's fashion sense. She knows how to dress for time, place and occasion.
Mosquito netting is fashionable?
It's healthy and fashionable both. Veils are making a comeback.
@BATTLE
You both know how to speak softly, but you each also carry a big stick. And I know you aren't afraid to use yours, much less point it at someone.
That's it! I have half a mind to just tie her down, wrap her up in furoshiki and present her to His Imperial Majesty as a gift!
Kitakami can't be that bad...
Yes, she can! That girl is soggier than a submarine, and even I-8 can keep seaweed out of her hair!
I already anticipated having to ambush her in order to make sure she was cleaned and trimmed before dressing, but it's impossible to think of her and not want to straighten her up now.

Fields.MenuText: True. The last time I checked, "peasant chic" doesn't require acting like an actual peasant.
Careful... she could end up your rock, Sisyphus.
You wouldn't happen to be letting any bias color your feelings, would you, Kongou? After all, she has more torpedoes than Carter has Little Liver Pills...

Fields.DialogueText: I agree completely, Kanchou.
I prefer to think of her as the bird who refuses to sing, Kanchou. I have taken the "wait" approach and had no results, so it's time to look to the other two.
Perish the thought, Kanchou. Although I would probably be more at ease if I didn't have nightmares of her slipping on her deck, hitting the firing button and launching a spread...
She's not making this any easier on herself, the cheeky--
How do you figure?
If she had given me her vital statistics, I could do my preparations without involving her until the event. ... Her response?
"Goodness, Kongou-sama, asking a lady's measurements? That's a rather personal question coming from you, don't you think?"
@BATTLE
What?!
--cho...! Kanchou--!
Kongou? ...What? I can't hear--
Captain, I believe she wants you to step back from the flight path.
... The what again?
For the darts. See the board, over there?
You mean that dartboard at the other end of... of the topdeck?!
Yes, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Well, at least she's trying to keep me from getting hit by a dart.
So, how full is the infirmary?
...Kongou!

Fields.DialogueText: Actually, Captain, she was shouting not to spoil her shot.
She hasn't sent a single person, Captain. She holds for onlookers too far over the edges... and the boatswain set us at the blind entrances onto the carpet, to prevent jaywalking.
Tell the boatswain to get my dartboard stowed. We have orders coming in.
Right away, Kongou no Kami. Captain?
Off you go.
Yes, Captain!
Before you break out the darts again, Kongou, we need to discuss your little hobby.
@BATTLE
... Kongou! Time out!
Sounds like someone just earned themselves a promotion for initiative and foresight. Hey! Kongou! We need to talk!
I'm already ahead of you, Kanchou.
Let us meet in battle, and come out victorious.
@BATTLE
So, what's possessed you to take up darts?
Kitakami no Kami. It seems she overheard Saguenay-san describing a past time of fur trappers: axe throwing.
She wouldn't.
She most certainly would, which is why I've acquired the dartboard and an assortment of darts.
If I can present her with an alternative, I believe I can keep her from using her own ceremonial axe in a manner that might be scandalous.

Fields.MenuText: And I thought Belles throwing darts was hazardous...
Besides the obvious, what's the harm? It's her axe, after all.
Assortment is right. Brass, wood...feather flights, paper ones...is all this necessary?

Fields.DialogueText: This is a sport, Kanchou, and I have rangefinders. I could stand closer to the board, but that would be too easy.
Aside from looking silly and having to provide a target thick enough to stop it, there's the issue of what happens if she misses. Axes don't float.
Absolutely, Kanchou. Brass darts vary so much in weight and grip that I want to give her a good amount to choose from - I won't let her use "it doesn't feel right" for an excuse.
What about your future plans for her? And your current ones, for that matter?
This crisis takes priority. If she went through with irreverence of this magnitude, she could get herself barred from an official audience. That's unthinkable!
If worst comes to worst when the time comes, I'll drop a tengai over her head, throw an o-kuwara over her shoulder, and claim she's taken vows as a monk!
Good point. I can just imagine one of the submarine Belles trying to claim salvage rights or holding it for ransom.
And the wood ones?
Essential for practice at sea, since they float.
Gotcha.
Inrō... or no inrō. That is the question.
I hope the answer has to do with our current mission.
My apologies, Kanchou. I was asked for advice on a style matter that requires some thought.

Fields.MenuText: A question that doesn't have an easy answer? I'm impressed.
Can't you just wait six months? The answer will probably be moot by then, either way.
I guess I can't blame you for letting your mind wander. Make sure it knows the fastest way home when the shooting starts. Okay?

Fields.DialogueText: We live in an age full of them, Kanchou.
I'm sure the Morganas would like us all to take that advice.
Point taken.
There's the signal. Now we can get on with our work here. I'll give my reply to Kumano-san later.
You mean it was a question Kumano asked? Now I'm curious.
I will be happy to tell you about it. First, however...
@BATTLE
A kimono is the answer.
Tsukesage, Kanchou.
I thought "inrō or no inrō" was the question.
And "no inrō" is the answer. Kumano-san asked me if it was acceptable to gift to Hachi no Kami a sporran... as substitute inrō.

Fields.MenuText: So I guess an inrō as a substitute sporran would also be out.
Even if she was wearing plaid?
Hachi no Kami?

Fields.DialogueText: Hmmm... yes, I'm afraid so. A tobacco pouch might work, but not an inrō.
If it actually got Hachi no Kami to wear SOMEthing when she was in a casual state, I'd give the idea my endorsement.
Hachi. Eight. Lady I-8. She encourages others to use her full name only in English... she finds "correcting" non-native speakers too much work.
Kumano-san thought our willful little submarine might appreciate it, since she has no pockets. *Hmph.* If she needs pockets badly enough she can use the sleeves of a simple tsukesage, I say.
Sure you aren't being too critical?
Critical?
You've reduced a pier full of sea lions down to cosmetics-grade blubber for swimming around where you couldn't see them.
Are you sure your opinions on a submarine's review uniform aren't a wee bit biased?
I'm not criticising her uniform, Kanchou.
You're not?
Not at all. I've already lectured her on that subject before... and she continues to respectfully point to her unique set of operating conditions.
For my efforts, I have at least secured from her assurances that, when in the presence of the Emperor, her swimming costume will match her sleeves and cap.
I see.
This problem Hachi no Kami has with pockets comes from her off-duty habit of swimming with fisher-maids.
The traditional ones, not the "white-wrapped tourist bait" the Mikimoto pearl company uses.
Honestly! When she's not on duty, she's brazen enough to wear nothing but a loincloth and swimming cap!
@BATTLE
Since I know she would never wear anything so clearly foreign however, there's not much point.
If you ever want to leave her truly speechless, Kanchou, pronounce the "I" like the 5th letter of the alphabet instead of the 9th, and add it to "Hachi".
That was unexpected...
She didn't answer your hails?
No, because Hachi-san hailed me, first. She reached out to me on behalf of all submarine Belles, due to my role as Voice for the Fleet.
All submarines... That sounds serious.
Indeed. Apparently, there's been a rash of near misses on them by non-Belle ship crews.
It seems the Atlantic is especially prone to it, but there are other places where any periscope is treated as belonging to an enemy or Funayūrei.
Treaty bands unseen, huh? That can't be pleasant. So, Ambassador Kongou, what's the plan?
I'd love to thank them politely for helping and tell them all to go home.

Fields.MenuText: That would go over like a lead balloon and you know it.
What? And miss an opportunity to aid your fellow Belles, after they came to you for it? Besides, it could be fun.
But you won't.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, yes, I know. I wouldn't bother to waste my breath in any case; they're all mad enough to ignore my advice, no matter how sane it is.
You're right, of course. I don't get to pick and choose when Duty calls.
*Sigh.* Hachi-san's too proud for her own good. She claims submarines are exempt from the hierarchy of naval vessels.
I reserve the right to forgo walking a mile in their shoes... fins... what have you.
Fair enough.
@BATTLE
It makes me wonder sometimes if their insanity isn't a built-in feature for them.
Of all the times for her to actually behave like a battleship of an undersea fleet...
I wonder if someone encouraged her...
Kanchou? Did you say something?
Nope... Nothing at all...
Kanchou! I believe I've solved the identification issue. It was simple, really. If the colored bands on their turrets can't be seen, use flares!
Yes, I see.
And the fastest way to put three flares in the sky is with a tri-barrel flare gun, of course. Which the Imperial Japanese Navy happens to have.
There'll be no "lowest bidder" folderol THIS time.
Correct me if I'm wrong, Kongou. No one in the Protection fleet sails with red-red-red bands.
Quite true, Kanchou. It's my favorite colour though, so while I'm testing the concept, I'm just using red flares.
I know you're aware what the International Maritime Distress signal is. You've got ships from here to Bora Bora calling in!
Well, shame on them! What kind of battleship would I be, that I needed to send up an actual distress signal?

Fields.MenuText: That signal is for all ships, from a Belle battleship to a Belle-less dinghy. Even you need to follow the rules, Kongou.
What if there's a ship out there, right now, that's really in distress. You'd feel bad if a signal from her was drowned out by your experiments, wouldn't you.
I know you're not intentionally trying to cry wolf, but if this keeps up that's exactly what's going to happen.

Fields.DialogueText: Hai, Kanchou. Does this mean I should refrain from using my tracer rounds from now on? Not a bit, since they thoughtfully point out an actual ship in distress.
I see your point, Kanchou. Should I discontinue this line of thinking, then?
Morganas! Port midships!
@BATTLE
No... I think you've just caught something early. So long as you work out a way to keep your ID method from being mistaken for a distress signal, I'd say you're on the right track.
If you were incapacitated and our radio out, it would be your crew sending up the distress signal, not you.
That's highly unlikely, Kanchou. Still, I see your point - I need to set an example to those with a greater risk.
So, red is still acceptable as long as it's part of some navy's stripe code?
For now. That, and you might want to give nearby ships a warning. Don't tell them what pattern though, and you'll find out how well your message is actually getting received.
I was wondering what that blunderbuss was for...
I can't blame you for calling it that. This Schermuly Rocket Pistol Apparatus is capable of shooting a rocket into the teeth of any storm, however. I think this should work rather nicely.
Not bad. But how does this solve the signal problem? Three-barrels didn't work, so I can't see how a single-barreled rocket cannon is supposed to work any better.
That's because of its role, Kanchou. Its primary use is as a line thrower.
Surely, if the rocket can pay out a stout line three hundred meters, it can carry a single meter of cord with a parachute and three flares attached.

Fields.MenuText: Which puts the red into Fleet colors context. You exchange the flares for smoke grenades during the day, I assume.
Correct me if I'm wrong, but "Schermuly" doesn't sound Japanese.
Where in the world did you get it?

Fields.DialogueText: Either that or streamers. I haven't decided yet.
It doesn't sound like an Englishman's name either, but rest assured- this is British made. ...There'll be no "lowest bidder" nonsense here, either.
From New Orleans-san, believe it or not. She said something about it not being "Voykov enough" - whatever that means...
Have you tried it out?
Not yet. And not now, it seems. The winds have shifted.
If you can only use the signal in good weather, then that's a problem, Kongou. I thought you said that thing could fire into the teeth of a storm. Unless...
That's correct, Kanchou - it's Morgana mist!
@BATTLE
Fair enough.
Let us meet in battle, and come out victorious.
@BATTLE
Sigh... Of course it's not simple...
If it were simple, they wouldn't have come to you. So, what's the problem now?
How to see a black flare at night.
Ha! That IS a tough one.
And of course one of the two navies affected would have to be Germany. They're the ones who need it the most.
I tried to use sparking flare to set black apart from white, but the observers keep interpreting it as a misfiring flare.

Fields.MenuText: Like that never happens.
Have you asked the submarines for advice?
If they're expecting a color to count it as a working flare, what about the dark end of the color spectrum and use purple?

Fields.DialogueText: It's not good when that happens either. One color can make the difference between Germany, Britain, Turkey and Poland.
Why would I do that, Kanchou? They're the ones asking for help in the first place.
It might work for Spain, but Blue and Purple are so similar, an unfamiliar spotter could mistake Britain and German colors.
Then, what about two blue flares counting as Black? You're just stringing them on a tether, so can't you add one more?
That would make Spain and Germany's signal four flares. Any idiot who could count could tell the difference between Britain and German signals...
Kanchou, that could work!
Sounds wonderful. Do I set course for Lisbon?
At the soonest opportunity! I'll test on the way!
I can just hear the Nazis now, whining that Purple is NOT Black...
And that's IF they'd consent to having purple represent black.
Kanchou...
Yes?
Why didn't they tell me sooner that all they needed was a single code to represent ANY Protection Force submarine?!

Fields.MenuText: Did you ask them?
It was rather sneaky... but even you have to admit you had fun firing off all those flares in the name of "research."
I'm not convinced it would have stopped you from still pursuing the neutrality stripe code even if you knew about it.

Fields.DialogueText: No.
My only regret was not finding a red substitute. To think that pink would still be interpreted as a distress signal... Oh well.
Well, what's the point of having Neutrality stripes at all, then? To make Haze Grey that much less appealing?
You did call the tri-barrel to their attention though, so that was something.
That doesn't help me decide what to do with the rest of the flares.
You have that many extra?
Certainly, Kanchou. I had enough made to carry through until the supply system could provide for the demand.
Then what's the problem?
The Protection Force can't use them. I experimented with how close I could get to another color before an observer had trouble making the proper identification.
Meaning...
Along with the sparkling ones, I have enough salmon, tangerine, gold, chartreuse, aquamarine...
Enough flares to last a lifetime. Gotcha.
@BATTLE
That's an interesting variation on darts. With the board on the deck like that, you have to make a parabolic shot, right?
Exactly. It's in my Immunity zone as well, so not only is this actually challenging, it's useful practice.
You certainly look like you're enjoying yourself. But, out here, playing darts? I thought you'd be hard at work, bringing the rest of the Imperial Navy Belles to ceremony-ready status.
I thought I'd pause on that for a bit, to re-examine my efforts.
Do tell...
With Mrs. Marker still engaged in the design stage for Kaga-san, it's hard to set a firm timeline.
You don't say.
Although, I have firm assurances all around that should His Imperial Majesty ever request our presence, everyone will attend appropriately groomed and dressed.
Sigh... I would be more reassured if I believed their definition of "appropriately groomed and dressed" agreed with mine.

Fields.MenuText: Even you have to agree that you set a pretty high bar, Kongou. These things always take time.
Didn't you tell me you had Kumano in your corner? And if... er... when the time comes, I'm sure the class-namers will also want to make sure their sisters pass muster.
Nobody is perfect, and unless there's a manual you Belles have. It's kind of hard to follow the rules if there aren't any.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, but... there are prints that are seasonal. At this rate, I can't guarantee when a request will happen, meaning yet more delays to properly coordinate everyone.
You have a point, Kanchou...
There are such things as unwritten rules, Kanchou.
So, what should I do about this mission?
Mission?
Headquarters wants to know whether or not Morgana spotters behave like a Belle's planes.
You mean the way we maintain contact with our aircraft, so long as they're airborne?
Right. It sounds risky, but they want to try to force one into landing, then see how the Morgana reacts.
Haha! Yes, that would be rewarding. So when do we start?
Are you sure we should take it? I mean, I don't want to take you away from your project...
I can always return to it later. Accept the mission, Kanchou! You have my encouragement!
As you wish, Kongou.
@BATTLE
I know that. But who sets them, Kongou, and how do you pass them on to those who need to follow them? I think you've been doing enough by leading through example up to this point.
